body: Thank you @mklaehn, I mess up the rebase, will keep working on it.

hi @BradWalker this was my fault. I introduced it with #3689. It looks like the jackpot rule couldn't box the type and I haven't noticed since the classes are not compiled during full build or tests.

The class has two more copies, could you update them too?
enterprise/performance.scripting/test/qa-functional/src/org/netbeans/performance/languages/actions/CountingSecurityManager.java
java/performance.java/test/qa-functional/src/org/netbeans/performance/j2se/actions/CountingSecurityManager.java

OK, so what about **documenting** these "API types" (which weren't meant to be actually exposed as API types) in NB Tooling gradle plugin as internal protocol scheduled for removal in NB 14+1 release - then refactor it to another package, so it does not clash with the real API ?

See also conversation at the end of the macOS vote thread - https://lists.apache.org/thread/8k4g47n8y7gyfbwhdmbhtryvjx30qdhd

Other option is to use an installer with bundled JDK runtime, under Community Installers at https://netbeans.apache.org/download/nb13/nb13.html  Then you can use the SDKMAN managed JDKs for projects.
https://security.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-MINIMIST-2429795 for the curious
Thank you for the suggestion. I exported the settings from version 12.6 and imported them into version 13. Unfortunately, it didn't do anything as far as I can tell.
I know that this is not a solution, but is it possible to try a JVM with HotSpot instead of OpenJ9? OpenJ9 has a terrible performance when starting in Debug mode.
OK, I don't have those directories on Mac.
The `About` window will show you the location of your user and cache directories.
I found it eventually at ~/Libraryt/Caches/Netbeans and yep seems to have done the trick.

Hello,
Unfortunately it's not possible, we've some constraints in my company and i'm forced to use openJ9.
Great! I'll close this.  If it recurs, please report back, especially if there's any further insight on what the trigger for it is.

Moving those two files out of the api package can be done by NB14. The sooner the better.
I can create a PR for that once this one is in.

Well, you might just check out NB 13 code change that timeout value and compile one for yourself.
Also it is possible to start Tomcat externally, then attach the debugger it.

This is a so rare case, that I do not feel introducing an API for it. Even as small as add a System Property to be able to change that timeout. Though others can have other opinion. You can also file a PR if you would like to push that through.

Hi, my code change may look weird, but this component is responsible for drawing the tab-bar in the editor area. This is only the part of the "North" component of a border layout. The minimum size of the actual content is the "Center" component and is considered by the panel.

You can check, that this works correctly by trying the Platform Application attached to the bug.
It contains only one relevant file: an editor window, registered with annotations, with a minimum size set and an overridden paint method to show the minimum size. If you like I can this file separately.

hmm. why can't the secondary jobs find the artifact in this PR. This never happened during testing.

looking at the first workflow run:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/runs/5769887724?check_suite_focus=true
1. base job uploaded successfully
2. secondary jobs could download, however, the file was corrupted and extraction failed
3. all secondary jobs failed, but the cleanup job removed the artifact successfully

All subsequent workflow runs fail with secondary jobs not finding any artifacts, despite the primary job getting a success msg after upload:
"Artifact build has been successfully uploaded!"

i have never seen something like that. might be a temp gh issue?
@jhorvath i deleted the complete workflow run. Could you do me a favor and force push into this PR to trigger a fresh run?

> It is pushed already, but just 3 checks are queued.

@jhorvath it works like a pipeline now. Two primary jobs build, rest starts later after they succeed and use the artifact of the primary build for tests.

the summary shows a nice graph https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/2071857027

anyway. Everything appears to be working fine now. This might just have been a weird anomaly. At least we know how to fix it if it happens again.

Hey @mbien ,

Most of the "rust removal" work that I do, is done to try and make it easy for a reviewer. For example, the "new Float" work this change covers should just be about Floats. I find it easier for me to make changes this way and if I had to review, it makes things easier for me to think in those terms.

Changes required for the "new Double" are going to be really large (i.e. lots of different files). So that really should stand on it's own.

Also, I did try and bundle together the Byte & Short changes since they were reasonable to do and review.

Can I count you as an approver? 8-)

BTW, hang in there.. I'm almost done..
Hey @lkishalmi , can I count you as a reviewer of this?

> This has also happened to me alot, it seems to be random, I still dont know what causes it, I'm not sure its related to the LAF but yea this has happened in previous versions too atleast since version 11. I haven't used versions 10 and 9.

I think NB11 hasn't had the new LAF - `FlatLaf light` yet at that time. Have you tried it with other LAFs on NB11?

Let me add some history on this.
So at the initial phase of the Gradle plugin, all JavaDoc and Source information was retrieved directly by the tooling plugin. These are treated as miscellaneous information. They are not serialized along the other project information,rather than kept a globally serialized artifact store updated.

With the introduction of the GradleModuleFileCache21 the globally serialized artifact store could be redundant, as the javadoc and source information could be retrieved directly from the cache.

So probably it would be wise to revisit the handling of this information and remove some code.

Yes, the description is misleading / wrong sorry; I am still working on some scenarios where serialized project is rejected despite the data in artifact store are still valid. For now just ignore the description - will update :) before going from draft stage.

Or do you mean the whole concept of the artifact store is superseded by the GradleModuleFileCache21 ?

> Or do you mean the whole concept of the artifact store is superseded by the GradleModuleFileCache21 ?

Yes. I think that's possible. At the moment I can't name any use-case where GradleModuleFileCache21 with additional heuristics for Maven and File dependencies would not be enough.
I see things are coming together :)
just tested it and its also reproducible while using javac of 17.0.2 and 18+36. So we can rule out it being nb-javac specific.

How about compatibility? This is not a small piece of code and it will (most likely) have problems in Theia.

@MartinBalin I think compatibility shouldn't be a problem, since we are just reusing the already existing `.vsix` packages to just upload them to a secondary location. `ovsx` uses `vsce` under the hood as well and the feature set should be close to the same. The code attached in the guide is a whole GitHub Action workflow, but if the package is already prepared, only one command needs to be executed:
```
npx ovsx publish path_to_vsix -p TOKEN
```

If you mean that the whole extension is not a small piece of code, I agree, but I'm down to doing some tests in Theia as well, if necessary.

Consolidated; description updated.

> So probably it would be wise to revisit the handling of this information and remove some code.

It could be much better, but we are about to release vscode in a few weeks, and I'd rather not to disrupt things. So far the changes made here are pretty local, not affecting other things than the loading process - and greatly improve project loading time.

Let's do the cleanup in a separate PR.
Please check the message log whether there are relevant entries. Please provide steps to reproduce.

> I'm not sure its related with the LAF, but I think I remember this happening in version 11. For me I was never able to reproduce it, it just happened randomly, so I'm not 100% sure

For me, this issue only happens when the code completion list needs to be re-positioned and the first item that appears in the list has a JavaDoc need to display. So, the conditions to reproduce are:
- Code completion list position needs to be adjusted accordingly to the edge of the viewport.
- And, the first item that appears in the Code completion list must have a JavaDoc to display.
- And, Netbeans goes with the LAF FlatLaf light.

> Thank you - the final part (not deleting artifacts on failure) is IMHO the most important I had to restart the full pipeline to fix two jobs, which kind of defeats the purpose.

Agreed. Thanks for the review. Lets get this merged so that job restarts can be used as advertised in the original PR.

to meet the JDK 8 requirement of this module I backported the hashcode workaround of lucene 9.0.0 to EOL lucene 8.11.1.

This is done by eagerly loading a patched version of MultiTermQuery. Two guards were added to make sure this hack doesn't break anything and ensure that it is removed on next upgrade.

1) if the unpatched class would be already loaded, this static init would fail and we would notice
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/63485d7744cf209f589ac9fc382df860a6e18ff0/java/maven.indexer/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/indexer/NexusRepositoryIndexerImpl.java#L126-L131

2) if lucene is upgraded without removing this hack, this assert will fail, so we can't forget about it:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/63485d7744cf209f589ac9fc382df860a6e18ff0/java/maven.indexer/src/org/apache/lucene/search/MultiTermQuery.java#L332-L341
@mbien thanks for checking!

You might have broken links on the Desktop.
Select root of a project. Choose from menu Tools/Open in Terminal.

Here is a simple Spring Boot project provided.

[netbeans-bug-springboot.zip](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/8407553/netbeans-bug-springboot.zip)

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open project with Netbeans 13 & Build project
2. Start editing file  `NetbeansBugDemoApplciation` (I was just copying/pasting/deleting log.info over and over to simulate working with a file) and after (a few minutes?) it freezes.

@jtulach Thank you for your answer. The idea of this issue to open project in terminal without opening and looking through project tree. In projects tab we first of all have projects. With right click on project (not on some of nodes of project tree) we should have ability to open project in terminal. Please, look, how it is implemented in other IDE's. 

I am not speaking here how to get the same result - there are a few ways to get it. I am talking how to get this result the most convenient way.

I agree with @PashaTurok - I think this is a valid feature request.  You can do it on package nodes, basic folders, etc. already.  Makes sense on project nodes, and something I used to find deeply frustrating.

The other workaround is to use `ALT-SHIFT-K` with a project or file selected.

> @BradWalker would this work?

Hey @mbien , it did and provided the inspiration to nail down the stragglers.  All references to raw type WeakReference are now cleaned up..

I saw this artifact when using an old userdir with NetBeans master. Given that you used a release version, I assume you imported all old modules into your new installation. This includes an old implementation of nbjavac, which must not be imported.

If you know your way around the userdir, remove the nbjavac module, if not, delete the userdir.

Apologies - I needed to rewrite the synchronization to the other proposed solution: the tests show that some code might rely on the priming build (that uses the loaded future) or the loaded future itself as trigger for further processing. At that time it was assumed that the project has already reloaded itself **including the lookup and action change**, which is done inside event handlers.

So now the previous state is maintained: the future completes only after the whole project is refreshed, but event receivers see a special completed future when they ask for it.

Sorry for the inconvenience.
This morning, I was able to overcome the problem unchecking "Automatically detect settings" from Proxy options, leaving only "Use setup script" checked and "Script location" filled

Unfortunately a long standing annoyance, which doesn't seem to have a definitive reproducible cause, or we know whether it's definitely NetBeans or the JDK at fault.  Have a read of https://lists.apache.org/thread/xqkwy4wxylmzprxl1wko301hlqz59r7d and some of the flags, logging settings, etc.  Be great to get to the bottom of this one!

@matthiasblaesing , would you please make a review of the changes?
- Added "TEST_DATA" to the list of comment types for licenseinfo.xml.
- Added "external/binaries-list" with a reference to this [precompiled binary GdbKillProc.exe for Windows](https://netbeans.osuosl.org/binaries/7315EB1AC148941FD18F9F1F71BD1DBECE67A501-GdbKillProc-1.exe)
- A patch that closes #3947 , making Cygwin gdb's working again. This was due to wrong paths being sent to the debugger.

NetBeans CND sporting the Cygwin's gdb debugger on Windows (NB8.2 failed at this, see #3947 ).
On the screenshot, a project configured with C++14 and a function with an `auto` argument. gdb seems to properly find the value of this variable.
![imagen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/564140/162753636-54e1514d-246d-4e84-8ce8-e9dd7b281784.png)

The debugger log file, after https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3909 is applied.
Now NetBeans is sending proper "Cygwin-like" file names to gdb again, so gdb can understand what we're debugging and where the breakpoints are.

[nb-gdb-log-2.txt](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/8464676/nb-gdb-log-2.txt)

The code is a swampland of potential legal issues. I see old NetBeans ClearCase files from original NB authors, which were not donated by Oracle to ASF. Also the dual ASF license header is not good for code that you would contribute.

I'm going to close this PR now. Waiting for the plugin on the plugin portal!
